s.text: We are exploring model-based meta-analysis of many arrays of the same chip type but hybridizing to a heterogeneous set of tissues samples, and will present such analysis in future work.

A global way of using SE in hierarchical clustering is to resample or bootstrap [ 8] the whole 'gene by sample' data matrix and redo the clustering, then investigate the overall properties emerging from this repertoire of clustering trees.

This difference provides a lower bound of biological variation that can be detected between two independently amplified samples, and serves as a good statistic for comparing different analytical methods.

Also note that GeneChip software excludes probes whose PM/MM difference is outside three standard deviations (SDs) of all probe differences in either of the two arrays in the comparison; here, as we are comparing multiple arrays at the same time, when calculating ADs a probe is excluded if its difference is an outlier in the above sense in any of the arrays, until a minimum of five probes is reached, where all five probes will be used).
As expression level becomes higher (when the target gene of a probe set is detected in more arrays), the AD method shows a rapid improvement in performance, approaching the level of the MBEI method.
As expression level becomes higher (when the target gene of a probe set is detected in more arrays), the AD method shows a rapid improvement in performance, approaching the level of the MBEI method.

As array images usually have different overall image brightness (Figure 9a), especially when they are generated at different times and places, proper normalization is required before comparing the expression levels of genes between arrays.
A high 'in-cluster' count indicates a gene 'remains' in the original cluster in most of the resampled clustering trees.
The availability of SEs for the model-based expression indexes allows us to obtain confidence intervals for fold changes.

We have developed a software package DNA-Chip Analyzer (dChip [ 10]) to perform invariant-set normalization (see below), calculation of MBEI [ 1], computation of confidence intervals of fold changes, and hierarchical clustering with resampling.
Conklin, personal communication), and others to calculate fold changes using only PM probes (F.
Thus the fold change around 2.5 for gene 11 is not as trustworthy as that for gene 1. Further examination reveals that this is due to the large SEs relative to the expression indexes for gene 11.
We can use Q to construct fixed-level tests and to invert them to obtain confidence intervals (CI) for fold changes [ 5].
In this manner, the measurement accuracy of expression values propagates to the estimation of fold changes.
Usually, low or negative expressions are truncated to a small number before calculating fold changes, and GeneChip also cautions against using fold changes when the baseline expression is absent.
For example, gene 1 has fold change 2.47 and a tight confidence interval (2.
In practice, we find it useful to sort genes by the lower confidence bound ('Lower CB' in Table 1), which is a conservative estimate of the fold change.
After obtaining expression indexes using AD or MBEI, fold changes can be calculated between two arrays for every gene and used to identify differentially expressed genes.

As array images usually have different overall image brightness (Figure 9a), especially when they are generated at different times and places, proper normalization is required before comparing the expression levels of genes between arrays.

We should base the normalization only on probe values that belong to non-differentially expressed genes, but generally we do not know which genes are non-differentially expressed (control or housekeeping genes may also be variable across arrays).
Here, we cannot obtain correct probe-sensitivity indexes because of the absence of the target gene.
